#T_RL=webanno.custom.Coref|type|BT_webanno.custom.Referent
#Text=XIV
#Text=It is astonishing how short a time it takes for very wonderful things to happen .

#Text=It had taken only a few minutes , apparently , to change all the fortunes of the little boy dangling his red legs from the high stool in Mr. Hobbs 's store , and to transform him from a small boy , living the simplest life in a quiet street , into an English nobleman , the heir to an earldom and magnificent wealth .
#Text=It had taken only a few minutes , apparently , to change him from an English nobleman into a penniless little impostor , with no right to any of the splendors he had been enjoying .

#Text=And , surprising as it may appear , it did not take nearly so long a time as one might have expected , to alter the face of everything again and to give back to him all that he had been in danger of losing .

#Text=It took the less time because , after all , the woman who had called herself Lady Fauntleroy was not nearly so clever as she was wicked ; and when she had been closely pressed by Mr. Havisham 's questions about her marriage and her boy , she had made one or two blunders which had caused suspicion to be awakened ; and then she had lost her presence of mind and her temper , and in her excitement and anger had betrayed herself still further .
#Text=All the mistakes she made were about her child .

#Text=There seemed no doubt that she had been married to Bevis , Lord Fauntleroy , and had quarreled with him and had been paid to keep away from him ; but Mr. Havisham found out that her story of the boy 's being born in a certain part of London was false ; and just when they all were in the midst of the commotion caused by this discovery , there came the letter from the young lawyer in New York , and Mr. Hobbs 's letters also .
#Text=What an evening it was when those letters arrived , and when Mr. Havisham and the Earl sat and talked their plans over in the library !
#Text=“ After my first three meetings with her , ” said Mr. Havisham , “ I began to suspect her strongly .
#Text=It appeared to me that the child was older than she said he was , and she made a slip in speaking of the date of his birth and then tried to patch the matter up .
#Text=The story these letters bring fits in with several of my suspicions .
#Text=Our best plan will be to cable at once for these two Tiptons , -- say nothing about them to her , -- and suddenly confront her with them when she is not expecting it .
#Text=She is only a very clumsy plotter , after all .
#Text=My opinion is that she will be frightened out of her wits , and will betray herself on the spot . ”
#Text=And that was what actually happened .

#Text=She was told nothing , and Mr. Havisham kept her from suspecting anything by continuing to have interviews with her , in which he assured her he was investigating her statements ; and she really began to feel so secure that her spirits rose immensely and she began to be as insolent as might have been expected .

#Text=But one fine morning , as she sat in her sitting-room at the inn called “ The Dorincourt Arms , ” making some very fine plans for herself , Mr. Havisham was announced ; and when he entered , he was followed by no less than three persons --
#Text=one was a sharp-faced boy and one was a big young man and the third was the Earl of Dorincourt .
#Text=She sprang to her feet and actually uttered a cry of terror .
#Text=It broke from her before she had time to check it .
#Text=She had thought of these new-comers as being thousands of miles away , when she had ever thought of them at all , which she had scarcely done for years .
#Text=She had never expected to see them again .
#Text=It must be confessed that Dick grinned a little when he saw her .
#Text=“ Hello , Minna ! ” he said .
#Text=The big young man -- who was Ben -- stood still a minute and looked at her .
#Text=“ Do you know her ? ” Mr. Havisham asked , glancing from one to the other .
#Text=“ Yes , ” said Ben .
#Text=“ I know her and she knows me . ”
#Text=And he turned his back on her and went and stood looking out of the window , as if the sight of her was hateful to him , as indeed it was .
#Text=Then the woman , seeing herself so baffled and exposed , lost all control over herself and flew into such a rage as Ben and Dick had often seen her in before .
#Text=Dick grinned a trifle more as he watched her and heard the names she called them all and the violent threats she made , but Ben did not turn to look at her .
#Text=“ I can swear to her in any court , ” he said to Mr. Havisham , “ and I can bring a dozen others who will .
#Text=Her father is a respectable sort of man , though he 's low down in the world .
#Text=Her mother was just like herself .
#Text=She 's dead , but he 's alive , and he 's honest enough to be ashamed of her .
#Text=He 'll tell you who she is , and whether she married me or not . ”
#Text=Then he clenched his hand suddenly and turned on her .
#Text=“ Where 's the child ? ” he demanded .
#Text=“ He 's going with me !
#Text=He is done with you , and so am I ! ”
